hints_html:
“Quarterly” compounding means that the investment is compounded four times per year.

An investment with initial value \(A_0\) compounded quarterly at interest rate \(r\) (per year) will grow to a value of

\[\begin{aligned} A(t)=A_0(1+r/4)^{4t}\end{aligned}\]

after a time \(t\) in years.

question: 1 (c)
sols_html:
Using the discrete compound interest formula with 4 compounds per year, we know that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \$12000=\$10000(1+0.12/4)^{4t},\end{aligned}\]

where t is the time in years required for the \$10 000 investment to grow to \$12 000. We want to solve for t. Dividing both sides by \$10000,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 1.2=(1+0.03)^{4t}.\end{aligned}\]

Taking the logarithm of both sides and simplifying,

\[\begin{aligned} \ln(1.2)= \ln\left(1.03^{4t}\right) = 4t \ln\left(1.03\right)\end{aligned}\]

Hence, the investment will take

\[\begin{aligned} t= \frac{\ln(1.2)}{4\ln(1.03)}\end{aligned}\]

years to grow to \$12000.

”A calculator would tell you that t is about 1.54 years.”
